SHORT.string: Swami Nishpapananda explains how to integrate Bhakti (devotion) into everyday life, emphasizing love for God as the highest path to liberation. He contrasts Bhakti with Jnana (knowledge) and shares stories illustrating how human relationships can be transformed into divine love. Practical methods include daily spiritual practice, mantra repetition, and cultivating devotion through chosen ideals. The talk highlights that Bhakti awakens through grace and consistent effort, turning worldly attachments into spiritual focus, ultimately leading to inner peace and divine connection.

LONG.markdown_string:
# Applying Bhakti in Daily Life

We are delighted and deeply grateful that Swami Nish Papaanandaanand, Assistant Minister of the Vedanta Society of St. Louis, has once again graced us with his presence. We are fully aware of the heavy responsibilities you carry, Swamiji, and we sincerely appreciate you taking the time over the past few weeks to be here with us. It is truly wonderful to have you.

Today’s lecture topic is the **Application of Bhakti in Daily Life**, and I can’t help but feel it might relate to something as simple as painting a house.

*Come here.*  
*Peace, peace, peace.*  
*Lead us from the changing to the unchanging.*  
*Lead us from darkness to light.*  
*Lead us from death to immortality.*  
*Fully illuminate us and guide us always with Your loving presence.*  
*Peace, peace, peace be everywhere.*

Well, good morning.

[Music]

It feels good to be here. And it’s a welcome respite from those weighty responsibilities, a chance to be in this warm center. So, I thank you for that—and for the wonderful food and conversation I’ve enjoyed since arriving.

As Diane mentioned, the subject is **the application of Bhakti in daily life**.

In Hinduism, there are two principal paths: the path of **Bhakti** and the path of **Jnana** (knowledge).  
- **Devotees** (Bhaktas) reach a personal God endowed with blessed qualities through a mutual, loving relationship.  
- Followers of the **Jnana Marga** reach the formless reality that is beyond thought and symbol.

The great teacher **Sri Shankaracharya**, a foremost exponent of the path of knowledge, once wrote that among all the means for Moksha—complete liberation from all bondage and sorrow—**devotion to God is the highest**.

Why would Shankara write such a thing?  
Because through intellect alone, through logic alone, we cannot realize God.  
The **heart must walk with the head**.  
Emotion must connect with intellect.  
The heart must **yearn for the Divine**.

**Without Bhakti, we are merely research students.**

Sri Ramakrishna put it even more plainly. He said that a *Pandit*—a scholar of the scriptures—**without devotion is like a donkey carrying a load of books**.  
Not only does he fail to receive the *rasa*, the nectar, but those books are heavy. This was, of course, before the days of flash drives—he had to carry all those books with him everywhere.

**Constant remembrance of God is called 'Bhakti'.**  
And truthfully, **we concentrate on what we love**.  
It is that very thing which carries us forward in this life.  
It is the **vector that determines the direction we will take after leaving this life**.

So what is it that carries an ordinary, well-adjusted person forward throughout their life?

Many years ago, while I was working in market research, a conversation brought this into sharp focus for me. Not long after graduating college, I was interviewing a man who inspected commercial properties for an insurance company. It was a long interview, and with most people, there comes a point where their mind wanders, and you have to work to keep them engaged. But this man was different—he completed his task with full attention, and I appreciated that greatly.

Later, he began to converse with me, and I was happy to talk. He started asking me many interesting questions. You see, when you grow older and learn something from life’s experience, you don’t want to leave without sharing it. And when you find someone on the right frequency, you want to share that insight. And that’s what was happening.

I don’t remember all the questions, but I remember this one:  
**“What was a slave in Egypt thinking while carrying stones for the pyramid?”**

Now, that is an excellent question.  
And I had no answer. So, I remained silent for a long time. Finally, he said:  
**He was thinking of his wife and children.**

How did a commercial insurance inspector from Alton, Illinois, know what a slave building the pyramids thousands of years ago was thinking?  
**Because he was human.**  
And for most human beings, our primary joy comes through intimate personal relationships. Even while engaged in intellectually challenging work, a part of the mind—consciously or subconsciously—continues to dwell on those primary relationships that bring us happiness.

This brings me to **Swami Sardaasaananda**. How many have heard of him? Not many.  
Swami Sardaasaananda lived a very long life. He was a disciple of Holy Mother Sri Sarada Devi and was known in our Order as Swami Gopesh Maharaj, respected for his spiritual attainment. In the later part of his life, he wrote a book about Holy Mother, and this is taken from that book.

He reflects on an incident that likely occurred when he was around 40. He had gone to visit a friend he hadn’t seen in a long time. This friend, a doctor about 40 years old, had a good practice and a fine reputation as a physician. After two sons, he had been blessed with a daughter, who was about a year and a half old at the time.

From childhood, this friend had been very fastidious about his clothes. If he went somewhere and found the seat wasn’t clean enough, he would first dust it off and then sit—or else he would remain standing. No one had ever seen him wear anything but spic-and-span clothes.

My friend was very happy to see me and came running. We began exchanging greetings and good wishes when his little daughter—the apple of his eye—came toddling over, raised her arms, and lisped, “Dada!”  
He immediately bent down, picked her up, and in an overflow of love for her, exclaimed:  
**“For her sake, I had to give up everything—even my fastidiousness! She will not take ‘no’ for an answer. I cannot put you down.”**

“As soon as she sees me, I immediately take her in my arms. When I come back from practice, I’m not allowed to change my clothes. She might be playing in the dust, but the moment she sees me, she comes running, and I have to pick her up right then and there. Otherwise, she would cry and turn the house upside down. I was able to keep myself distant from my sons—they were not allowed to sit in my lap—but I could not save myself from her.”

“Look now. She is rolling on the ground, and there is dust and dirt all over her body. But as soon as she saw me standing there, she came running.”

And saying this, my friend’s gaze turned back to his daughter, and he embraced her again, the joy of his heart shining through his face and eyes.

I saw and heard this, and the thought arose in my mind:  
**Perhaps it is to taste this very joy in life that one adopts family life.**

He was a very good observer of human life.  
My friend’s sons were born when he was very young. Perhaps then the lotus of his heart had not fully bloomed. Perhaps at that time, the nectar of love was not so abundant.

I was very happy to see my friend’s happy family. Much later, when he was over 80 and unable to move about much, I learned that it was this same daughter who was caring for him. Thus, by serving her father with love and respect, she not only relieved his sorrow and suffering but made her own life blessed as well.

You see, **whatever is deeply impressed upon the mind becomes a concern and carries us with it**.  
And this holds true even for those who find their engagement with life to be more rational than emotional.

We had a doctor in St. Louis who moved to another city. He called and told me he had been diagnosed with cancer—and he told me what kind. I knew it was a type of cancer that often takes people very quickly. In his case, it didn’t progress that way—but that was the expectation.

And I was astonished because there was a **joy in his voice** that I had never heard before. So my full attention was on him.

Well, it turned out that immediately after the diagnosis, both of his daughters—one of whom was also a doctor beginning her specialty training in another part of the country, and the other teaching abroad—picked up all their things and moved their families to the city where he lived, very close to him.

Then I thought, *Now I understand the joy in his voice*. But he was trying to be very matter-of-fact about it, and he finished telling the story. He said,  
**“So, eight more mammals.”**

I was thinking, *What is he talking about?*  
Well, that’s the two daughters, two sons-in-law, two grandchildren, and two dogs.  
He was somehow clinging to his rationality.

The joy was that his daughters loved him so much that they would not live apart from him when he truly needed them.

Therefore, when the mind turns toward God, it is natural and highly effective to reach God through human relationships—**and any human relationship can be made divine**.

The practical problem is this:  
That mind, which for many births has been churning in the ocean of the world—the ocean of life and death—is entangled in the world. How can it be turned so that it begins to churn in the opposite direction and becomes entangled in God?

**How can our concern for the world be transformed into concern for God?**  
How can devotion to the world be transformed into devotion, Bhakti, divine love for God?

Now, the topic is the **application of Bhakti in daily life**.  
So, do you fill a bucket with Bhakti and roll it onto the wall with a roller?  
Do you use a 2-inch trim brush or a 4-inch house brush to brush Bhakti on the wall in daily life?  
Or can you tell what I’m doing?  
Or do you take an air compressor, tape up the windows, and spray it on the side of the house?  
Or if you’re feeling really enthusiastic, do you put the intake hose down into the bucket of Bhakti and machine-gun it onto the wall of Maya’s windows, etc.?

It’s a question of **nature and method**.

Every analogy has its limits, and this one has many.  
You don’t buy a bucket of Bhakti from the hardware store or the paint store.  
**It is an inherent thing that must be awakened.**  
We all carry it within our hearts.

Devotion to the world is really devotion to the **Infinite and Unchanging**—a pseudo-form of devotion to the limited and changing.  
And that love of God usually doesn’t ignite within us until we come into contact with those in whom that flame is already burning.  
**God’s grace comes through those who have already received it.**

Now, please excuse me.  
In St. Louis, we have a large lectern, and I’m able to flip pages behind it like this. So sometimes when I have an appendix, I put it behind the previous page.  
Alright. So, it takes me a little time to shuffle things around.

This is about **Holy Mother Sarada Devi** when she was 13 years old. It was her first opportunity. She was at Kamarpukur when Sri Ramakrishna came from Dakshineswar. This was her first chance to spend some time with him. Of course, she was married to him, but it was really a betrayal—she didn’t actually live with him until she was 17. But this was her first opportunity to see what kind of person she had married.

I’ll put it this way.  
Later, she said:  
**“I know I never saw his face sad or irritated. He was always shining with joy. Whether he was in Samadhi, or with a great person, or with a five-year-old child, I never saw him sad. I always felt as though a jar of joy had been filled in my heart. It is impossible to describe that divine joy which is brimming over. And since then, it has been pouring. Oh, my God!”**

Now, Holy Mother’s case is extraordinary. Sri Ramakrishna was extraordinary, to say the least. But something similar can happen even in the case of an ordinary Guru and disciple. And there is an example—and sometimes it happens very slowly and imperceptibly, but sometimes it happens more dramatically.

I witnessed such an event years ago when I was first becoming interested in the divine. I was still a student and had started coming to the Sunday lectures. At a certain point, an engineer, about 40 years old, began attending—always in immaculate clothes, in a white suit, military posture, perfectly straight.

And after the talk, Swami Satprakashananda—who later became my Guru—would come to the library near the chapel and sit informally with those who came. Not everyone came in. And when I overcame my shyness and started sitting there, I noticed that whenever this gentleman came to a service for the first time, he would come straight into the library, sit at the table, and start firing questions at Swami Satprakashananda.

I never saw anyone else sit with him at that library table. Everyone else sat around the edges of the room, and people asked questions with great hesitation, but his voice was very loud, and it seemed as if all the questions were lined up in his mind, and he had finally found someone who could answer these complex questions—about the Upanishads and all those things he had been thinking about. He knew Sanskrit. He had been studying these things. He had become interested.

And one day, I was sitting behind Swami, and this gentleman was sitting on the other side of the table, asking his questions loudly. The subject was Karma—Sanchita Karma, Prarabdha Karma—I mean, he was going into the nuances and reached Prarabdha Karma. Swami was answering his questions very systematically, not going into great detail, just giving an intellectual answer to an intellectual question.

The subject was Prarabdha, and the gentleman answered loudly, and I could see from behind how Swami’s posture changed, and I heard his voice change from very polite and calm. Suddenly, there was an authority in his voice, and he looked across the table with a gaze—I couldn’t see his gaze, but I imagine it was one of those that goes through your eyes and down to your toes.

**“Do you know how much Karma you have on your shoulders?”**

Prarabdha Karma is the karma we have in this life. If an arrow has been shot, it will continue at full speed until it hits the ground. Okay. **Do you know how much Karma you have on your shoulders?**

And the gentleman’s demeanor changed.  
The expression in his eyes, the expression on his face—and he said nothing. His hands went up, his head bowed, and he said,  
**“I don’t know.”**

You know, the change was **instantaneous and permanent**. That was the remarkable thing. The change was immediate, not temporary—**permanent**.  
He never again sat at the library table. He sat outside with everyone else.  
The white suit never appeared again. He wore simple clothes, and his appearance was very attractive—he looked like a brown Paul Newman. Very attractive appearance, and he never said anything.

And then, after a while, he didn’t even sit. He would stand near the exit where Swami would have to pass when leaving the room. And every time Swami Satprakashananda went by, when he reached the gentleman, his hands would go up, and he would say, **“Please bless me.”**  
He was asking for initiation, spiritual initiation.

And Swami would say, “Oh, you know these things take time, be patient, don’t worry, be patient.” And he was not patient at all.

So this went on for some time, and his wife said to him at home one day, “You know, I want a Japa mala. I want a rosary to do my prayers, to do my Japa. Why don’t you ask Swami for a Japa mala?”

And the gentleman said, “You should pay attention to how much attention Swami pays to my requests. Why don’t you ask him?”

So the lady was not shy either, so the next time she saw an opportunity, she cornered Swami on the main stair landing near the pigeonhole and said, “Swami, I want a Japa mala. Can you give me a Japa mala?”

And he said, “Oh, I only give malas when I give initiation.”

And she asked, “When can you give me initiation?”

And he said, “Well, I’ll have to find an auspicious day. I’ll call and let you know.”

And he said, “Oh, by the way, you can bring your husband, too. I think he also wants initiation.”  
So, two for the price of one.

Once the **love of God is awakened**, how do we nurture and develop it?  
It becomes a matter of **removing obstacles**.

The desire for the **Infinite, Eternal, and Perfect** is what drives us to seek wealth, position, love, friendship, and power. And that is why our mind refuses to be satisfied with anything limited and imperfect.

Swami Vivekananda says that we are **infinite dreamers**. It is the Infinite. The soul dreams finite dreams, and they can never satisfy us. **Only the Infinite can satisfy us.**

Or the same idea can be put a little differently:  
He said the universe is the **debris of the Infinite cast on the shores of the finite**.

That is the renunciant.

Once we awaken and begin to turn the ship, it is essential that we **set aside some time every day exclusively for God**.  
If we do not do this, we will not be able to remember God while we do our work.

That daily routine.  
And that time for God usually takes the form of worship, ritual, repetition of God’s name, or meditation in our tradition. But it doesn’t necessarily have to.

And if we do not remember God very well during that time when we are making our daily effort, it doesn’t matter so much.

And many times, especially in the beginning, we want to give up because, frankly, it’s very bad. Sometimes you feel you are going backward. And one should not be discouraged by this because it is common that when you are moving forward, you feel you are going backward.

Over time, this daily effort will transform us, and we will be able to practice Karma Yoga and offer our worldly actions...
## The Alchemy of Attention: From Distraction to Divine Remembrance

The story of Norman—the self-deprecating Texan with his dollar-bill ID and sudden, life-altering vision of love while reading *Sports Illustrated*—reveals something essential about Bhakti. It isn’t manufactured; it’s *awakened*. It surfaces not in spite of our quirks, but often through them. Norman wasn’t trying to achieve a spiritual breakthrough. He was simply being himself, engaged in a mundane activity, when grace descended and re-wired his perception of reality. From that day forward, he was never lonely again. He didn't become a saint; he remained a businessman with a wry sense of humor, but his inner center of gravity had irrevocably shifted.

This points to a profound truth: the initial stages of spiritual practice are less about *attaining* something new and more about *uncovering* a connection that is already there, buried under layers of habit and distraction. The mind, accustomed to its worldly entanglements, does not easily turn toward God. The initial efforts can feel clumsy, even futile.

**The initial struggle is not a sign of failure; it is the friction of reorientation.**

### The Power of the Chosen Ideal & The Mantra

This is where the two crucial pillars of practice in our tradition come in: the **Chosen Ideal of God** (Ishta) and the **Mantra**.

Your Chosen Ideal is that particular facet of the Divine that naturally captivates your heart—be it as a protective mother, a compassionate friend, a divine child, or a stern but just king. Their stories, their teachings, their very image, should stir a feeling of enthusiasm and love within you. As a young man new to this path, I understood this intellectually. The logic was clear: by deeply contemplating a divine personality whose qualities you admire, those very qualities begin to cast their shadow upon you.

But the second pillar, the Mantra, was initially a mystery to me. In the early 70s, amidst the influx of Eastern traditions, mantra meditation was becoming popular, yet I was skeptical. My skepticism was ironically cemented by a scientific study that found no difference in measured physiological effects between chanting Sanskrit mantras and repeating the word "Coca-Cola." It seemed to reduce this sacred tool to a mere sound.

My perspective changed through a personal, and somewhat comical, misadventure. Hearing an elderly swami chanting what I thought was a mantra with such devotion, I decided to try it myself. The effect was immediate and powerful. In my demanding job working with troubled teens, this practice created a profound sense of detachment. I became like an observer watching a show, unfazed by their attempts to provoke me. While this was initially pleasant, I soon realized it was a problem. I was being paid to *engage*, not to witness dispassionately.

When I confessed this to the elderly swami, he was aghast. I had been unknowingly using a mantra meant for the path of knowledge (Jnana), which cultivates witness consciousness. It was the wrong tool for my devotional temperament. Later, when I received a mantra aligned with Bhakti, the effect was entirely different—it was warm, connective, and heart-opening.

**A mantra is not a neutral sound. It is a seed of consciousness, impregnated with a specific spiritual power (Shakti) that germinates a particular devotional mood (Bhava).**

When you repeat a mantra over time, you begin to inhabit the devotional mood it generates. I could never have imagined how a single, simple word could so dramatically alter the texture of one’s life. I still cannot explain it intellectually, but from experience, I understand it works—especially when it is given by someone in whom the flame of divine love is already burning.

### The Shift in Center: From "How are you?" to "I am fine."

This entire journey of Bhakti precipitates a fundamental shift in our center of gravity. We see this in how we answer the most mundane of questions: "How are you?"

In our conventional culture, this question is addressed to our empirical self—our health, our job, our investments, our family. And we are expected to give a brief, socially acceptable, and almost always positive answer. My aunt would expertly deflect the question to talk about her children and grandchildren. A devotee named Veronica, however, would ask "How are you?" and genuinely want to know *everything*, no matter how difficult. Answering her was like taking a medicine; you had to pay for it.

But when we progress on this path of devotion, a change occurs. Our attention becomes focused on how we are doing in our *inner life*. The physical and material circumstances still exist, but they move from the center to the periphery.

I have a friend, a wonderfully simple and direct woman, who exemplified this. In her late 80s, she went to a clinic and a young doctor asked her the routine question. She proceeded to list her ailments—a heart valve, arthritis, and several other age-related issues. The doctor listened intently, his head sinking lower with each new condition. When she finished, she looked at him, broke into a girlish laugh, and said, **"But I am fine."**

Her body was falling apart, but *she* was fine. Her identity was no longer fused with her physical vessel. This is the freedom Bhakti offers.

In Hindu imagery, Yama, the god of death, carries a noose. If we think we are the body, and the body is dying, most people don't want to go. So Yama needs a noose to pull us out. On the other hand, if we are focused on our inner life and regard the body as peripheral, we can witness the process of the body dying and say, "I am fine." We can actively participate in the process of dying. It is entirely different, and Yama has much less work to do. He doesn't need to pull us out.

### Maintaining the Devotional Mood Amidst Distractions

The final, practical challenge is this: how do we maintain this devotional focus when the world constantly intrudes? How do we go to the altar or sit for meditation with a heart full of love when we are still simmering from a recent annoyance?

The comic strip *Peanuts* offers a perfect illustration. Lucy is holding forth on her modern philosophies, until Pigpen, covered in dust, walks by and disrupts her. You see her face contort in rage, speed lines coming from her mouth as she screams at him. In the next panels, Pigpen is sent flying. She then composes herself, turns back to the reader, and says, **"I love mankind... it's people I can't stand!!"**

So how do we deal with the "people we can't stand" who threaten our hard-won peace?

One powerful method is to *bless them*. If someone is disturbing you during your meditation, bless them. Pray for their welfare. As you pray for their well-being, a remarkable thing happens: *you* start to feel better, and the mental image of them that was agitating you begins to soften. Then you can regain your concentration and continue your practice.

This is not about being a doormat; it is about actively wielding a spiritual tool to disarm a mental distraction. It is the application of Bhakti as a practical, psychological technology for inner peace.

The ultimate example of this unshakable inner poise was Swami Bhuteshananda, a former president of our Order. It was said of him that "his enemy was never born." He had a beautiful, transcendent smile. On one occasion, another swami was aggressively suggesting that the older monks should step aside for the youth. Swami Bhuteshananda remained utterly unshaken, offering no resistance. As the man persisted, Swami Bhuteshananda finally responded, very slowly and softly, **"Our shoes are not big enough for your feet."**

The message was delivered with such gentle finality that it stopped the conflict cold. This is the power that comes from a heart so established in the Divine that it cannot be perturbed by the petty ambitions of others.

For those of us who have not yet reached that level, the path is one of daily, diligent practice: returning to our Chosen Ideal, repeating our Mantra, and using the tool of blessing to transform our irritations into offerings. It is a gradual, often messy, but ultimately joyous realignment of our entire being toward the source of all love.

This journey of turning our innate capacity for devotion toward the Infinite prepares us for the final, most profound stage of the path: learning to see the Divine not just in the quiet of meditation, but in every face, every interaction, and every circumstance of our daily life.
## The Final Integration: When Bhakti Becomes Your Breath

The journey of applying Bhakti in daily life culminates not in a state of perpetual, ecstatic bliss, but in something far more integrated and sustainable—a fundamental reorientation of perception where the sacred and the mundane are no longer separate realms. This final stage is less about *doing* devotion and more about *being* devotional, where the practices discussed earlier—blessing irritations, shifting identity from body to soul—become as natural as breathing.

### The Vision That Changes Everything

We see this transformation vividly in the experience of Swami Vijnanananda, whose profound vision of the infant Krishna (Bal Gopal) did not lead him to withdraw from the world in solitary ecstasy, but propelled him deeper into service. After the divine vision faded, he encountered a devastating famine in Murshidabad. Against the advice of his brother disciples, he stayed. He did not leave until he could secure food for the starving and eventually started an orphanage for boys who had lost their parents. He spent the next forty years of his life worshipping God in those boys and villagers, "as a mother worships her child."

This is the ultimate test and triumph of applied Bhakti. The highest spiritual experience of being near Brahman did not make him aloof; it grounded him in compassionate action. He returned to the ordinary human level, but he returned with a devotional lens permanently affixed. The luminous soul, as the text states, "adopts a devotional attitude and sees God through the people and living beings with whom it interacts." Sri Ramakrishna called this "the full knowledge." This is the state of being fully on the path of Brahman, where one has searched for the Infinite and then returned to see that very Infinite within the finite.

### The Messy, Human Process of Painting the Wall

A question from the audience highlights a common struggle: the tension between seeking God in special, external places (like pilgrimage sites) and finding the Divine right at home. The answer provided is reassuringly practical. It’s a natural evolutionary process. Initially, an external environment might be necessary to kindle that devotion. But once the devotion ignites to a certain point, you will simply want to abide with it, regardless of location.

The metaphor of painting a wall is perfectly extended here. The goal is a painted wall—a life infused with Bhakti. It doesn't matter if you start messy, using your hands to smear the paint, and later finish with a roller or brush. The human life is a bit messy, and this approach to God can be messy, but you just keep applying yourself. "You keep applying Bhakti to the wall of Maya, and eventually, it works." The key is direction and persistence, not a perfectly straight, unblemished line. The divine discontent, the longing itself, is the "midday sun that heralds the dawn of knowledge." It is that very longing that leads you to God.

### Distilling the Paths: Karma Yoga and Bhakti Yoga

A sophisticated question from an attendee named Ravi cuts to the heart of the matter: What is the real difference between Karma Yoga (the yoga of selfless action) and Bhakti Yoga (the yoga of devotion) when, in practice, they seem so intertwined?

The clarification is essential. The traditional view is that Karma Yoga is a preparation for Bhakti Yoga (or Jnana Yoga). The purpose of Karma Yoga, as Shankaracharya explained, is to purify the mind to such an extent that we have a natural tendency to remember our spiritual ideal or abide in the Atman. The demarcation comes at the point where you no longer need Karma Yoga to purify the mind. When surrender to a personal God, or to the absolute, arises spontaneously within you, the *need* to practice Karma Yoga as a discipline falls away—though you may continue to act if your responsibilities require it.

In essence, Karma Yoga scrubs the vessel clean; Bhakti Yoga fills it with divine love.

### The Personal Experiment of a Lifetime

The final insights bring everything back to the individual's sincere, personal effort. There is no "silver bullet," be it a mantra or a specific technique. If you are of a certain age, you know that nothing is a "take it and you're done" proposition. You have to take it and apply it assiduously. If you are not ready to apply it assiduously, you should wait until the longing becomes a little more compelling.

The most crucial practical advice for sustaining this in daily life is to develop regular habits. For most of us, transforming our lives into a series of "experiments" through regular routines is non-negotiable. This includes regularity in spiritual practice, eating, and sleep. When we live a regulated life, it becomes easy to identify what is causing a disturbance in our mental equilibrium. If we live a random life, it is very difficult to pinpoint what we are doing that is throwing our mind off balance.

You don't have to do everything. The spiritual qualities we read about are the characteristics of enlightened souls; they come naturally to them because they have accessed the source of those qualities. For us, if we take one or two things as our practice, as we advance, all the rest will be included because they are all interconnected.

### The Grace of Waiting

The beautiful story of Swami Satprakashananda's impatience for initiation serves as a profound final lesson. After trying to force the issue and failing, he learned from a senior swami that the mantra, the grace, "is given." It comes through grace. This changed his entire attitude from one of demanding to one of receptive waiting. His longing remained, but it was now coupled with humility.

This is the final, integrated understanding of applying Bhakti in daily life. It is a dance between our most ardent, personal effort and a patient, humble receptivity to grace. We paint the wall with all the energy we have, but we must also recognize that the paint itself is a gift. We cultivate longing, we establish regularity, we serve, we bless, we see the divine in the faces around us—and we do it all with the quiet confidence that our efforts are not in vain. We are slowly, messily, and beautifully painting the wall of our own consciousness with the colors of the divine, until one day, we realize the wall was never really there at all.

# Applying Bhakti in Daily Life

We are delighted and deeply grateful that Swami Nish Papaanandaanand, Assistant Minister of the Vedanta Society of St. Louis, has once again graced us with his presence. We are fully aware of the heavy responsibilities you carry, Swamiji, and we sincerely appreciate you taking the time over the past few weeks to be here with us. It is truly wonderful to have you.

Today’s lecture topic is the **Application of Bhakti in Daily Life**, and I can’t help but feel it might relate to something as simple as painting a house.

*Come here.*  
*Peace, peace, peace.*  
*Lead us from the changing to the unchanging.*  
*Lead us from darkness to light.*  
*Lead us from death to immortality.*  
*Fully illuminate us and guide us always with Your loving presence.*

As Diane mentioned, the subject is **the application of Bhakti in daily life**.

In Hinduism, there are two principal paths: the path of **Bhakti** and the path of **Jnana** (knowledge).  
- **Devotees** (Bhaktas) reach a personal God endowed with blessed qualities through a mutual, loving relationship.  
- Followers of the **Jnana Marga** reach the formless reality that is beyond thought and symbol.

The great teacher **Sri Shankaracharya**, a foremost exponent of the path of knowledge, once wrote that among all the means for Moksha—complete liberation from all bondage and sorrow—**devotion to God is the highest**.

Why would Shankara write such a thing?  
Because through intellect alone, through logic alone, we cannot realize God.  
The **heart must walk with the head**.  
Emotion must connect with intellect.  
The heart must **yearn for the Divine**.

**Without Bhakti, we are merely research students.**

Sri Ramakrishna put it even more plainly. He said that a *Pandit*—a scholar of the scriptures—**without devotion is like a donkey carrying a load of books**.  
Not only does he fail to receive the *rasa*, the nectar, but those books are heavy. This was, of course, before the days of flash drives—he had to carry all those books with him everywhere.

**Constant remembrance of God is called 'Bhakti'.**  
And truthfully, **we concentrate on what we love**.  
It is that very thing which carries us forward in this life.  
It is the **vector that determines the direction we will take after leaving this life**.

So what is it that carries an ordinary, well-adjusted person forward throughout their life?

Many years ago, while I was working in market research, a conversation brought this into sharp focus for me. Not long after graduating college, I was interviewing a man who inspected commercial properties for an insurance company. It was a long interview, and with most people, there comes a point where their mind wanders, and you have to work to keep them engaged. But this man was different—he completed his task with full attention, and I appreciated that greatly.

Later, he began to converse with me, and I was happy to talk. He started asking me many interesting questions. You see, when you grow older and learn something from life’s experience, you don’t want to leave without sharing it. And when you find someone on the right frequency, you want to share that insight. And that’s what was happening.

I don’t remember all the questions, but I remember this one:  
**“What was a slave in Egypt thinking while carrying stones for the pyramid?”**

Now, that is an excellent question.  
And I had no answer. So, I remained silent for a long time. Finally, he said:  
**He was thinking of his wife and children.**

How did a commercial insurance inspector from Alton, Illinois, know what a slave building the pyramids thousands of years ago was thinking?  
**Because he was human.**  
And for most human beings, our primary joy comes through intimate personal relationships. Even while engaged in intellectually challenging work, a part of the mind—consciously or subconsciously—continues to dwell on those primary relationships that bring us happiness.

This brings me to **Swami Sardaasaananda**. How many have heard of him? Not many.  
Swami Sardaasaananda lived a very long life. He was a disciple of Holy Mother Sri Sarada Devi and was known in our Order as Swami Gopesh Maharaj, respected for his spiritual attainment. In the later part of his life, he wrote a book about Holy Mother, and this is taken from that book.

He reflects on an incident that likely occurred when he was around 40. He had gone to visit a friend he hadn’t seen in a long time. This friend, a doctor about 40 years old, had a good practice and a fine reputation as a physician. After two sons, he had been blessed with a daughter, who was about a year and a half old at the time.

From childhood, this friend had been very fastidious about his clothes. If he went somewhere and found the seat wasn’t clean enough, he would first dust it off and then sit—or else he would remain standing. No one had ever seen him wear anything but spic-and-span clothes.

My friend was very happy to see me and came running. We began exchanging greetings and good wishes when his little daughter—the apple of his eye—came toddling over, raised her arms, and lisped, “Dada!”  
He immediately bent down, picked her up, and in an overflow of love for her, exclaimed:  
**“For her sake, I had to give up everything—even my fastidiousness! She will not take ‘no’ for an answer. I cannot put you down.”**

“As soon as she sees me, I immediately take her in my arms. When I come back from practice, I’m not allowed to change my clothes. She might be playing in the dust, but the moment she sees me, she comes running, and I have to pick her up right then and there. Otherwise, she would cry and turn the house upside down. I was able to keep myself distant from my sons—they were not allowed to sit in my lap—but I could not save myself from her.”

“Look now. She is rolling on the ground, and there is dust and dirt all over her body. But as soon as she saw me standing there, she came running.”

And saying this, my friend’s gaze turned back to his daughter, and he embraced her again, the joy of his heart shining through his face and eyes.

I saw and heard this, and the thought arose in my mind:  
**Perhaps it is to taste this very joy in life that one adopts family life.**

He was a very good observer of human life.  
My friend’s sons were born when he was very young. Perhaps then the lotus of his heart had not fully bloomed. Perhaps at that time, the nectar of love was not so abundant.

I was very happy to see my friend’s happy family. Much later, when he was over 80 and unable to move about much, I learned that it was this same daughter who was caring for him. Thus, by serving her father with love and respect, she not only relieved his sorrow and suffering but made her own life blessed as well.

You see, **whatever is deeply impressed upon the mind becomes a concern and carries us with it**.  
And this holds true even for those who find their engagement with life to be more rational than emotional.

We had a doctor in St. Louis who moved to another city. He called and told me he had been diagnosed with cancer—and he told me what kind. I knew it was a type of cancer that often takes people very quickly. In his case, it didn’t progress that way—but that was the expectation.

And I was astonished because there was a **joy in his voice** that I had never heard before. So my full attention was on him.

Well, it turned out that immediately after the diagnosis, both of his daughters—one of whom was also a doctor beginning her specialty training in another part of the country, and the other teaching abroad—picked up all their things and moved their families to the city where he lived, very close to him.

Then I thought, *Now I understand the joy in his voice*. But he was trying to be very matter-of-fact about it, and he finished telling the story. He said,  
**“So, eight more mammals.”**

I was thinking, *What is he talking about?*  
Well, that’s the two daughters, two sons-in-law, two grandchildren, and two dogs.  
He was somehow clinging to his rationality.

The joy was that his daughters loved him so much that they would not live apart from him when he truly needed them.

Therefore, when the mind turns toward God, it is natural and highly effective to reach God through human relationships—**and any human relationship can be made divine**.

The practical problem is this:  
That mind, which for many births has been churning in the ocean of the world—the ocean of life and death—is entangled in the world. How can it be turned so that it begins to churn in the opposite direction and becomes entangled in God?

**How can our concern for the world be transformed into concern for God?**  
How can devotion to the world be transformed into devotion, Bhakti, divine love for God?

It’s a question of **nature and method**.

Every analogy has its limits, and this one has many.  
You don’t buy a bucket of Bhakti from the hardware store or the paint store.  
**It is an inherent thing that must be awakened.**  
We all carry it within our hearts.

Devotion to the world is really devotion to the **Infinite and Unchanging**—a pseudo-form of devotion to the limited and changing.  
And that love of God usually doesn’t ignite within us until we come into contact with those in whom that flame is already burning.

This is about **Holy Mother Sarada Devi** when she was 13 years old. It was her first opportunity. She was at Kamarpukur when Sri Ramakrishna came from Dakshineswar. This was her first chance to spend some time with him. Of course, she was married to him, but it was really a betrayal—she didn’t actually live with him until she was 17. I’ll put it this way.

Now, Holy Mother’s case is extraordinary. Sri Ramakrishna was extraordinary, to say the least. But something similar can happen even in the case of an ordinary Guru and disciple. And there is an example—and sometimes it happens very slowly and imperceptibly, but sometimes it happens more dramatically.

I witnessed such an event years ago when I was first becoming interested in the divine. I was still a student and had started coming to the Sunday lectures. At a certain point, an engineer, about 40 years old, began attending—always in immaculate clothes, in a white suit, military posture, perfectly straight.

And after the talk, Swami Satprakashananda—who later became my Guru—would come to the library near the chapel and sit informally with those who came. Not everyone came in. And when I overcame my shyness and started sitting there, I noticed that whenever this gentleman came to a service for the first time, he would come straight into the library, sit at the table, and start firing questions at Swami Satprakashananda.

I never saw anyone else sit with him at that library table. Everyone else sat around the edges of the room, and people asked questions with great hesitation, but his voice was very loud, and it seemed as if all the questions were lined up in his mind, and he had finally found someone who could answer these complex questions—about the Upanishads and all those things he had been thinking about. He knew Sanskrit. He had been studying these things. He had become interested.

Swami was answering his questions very systematically, not going into great detail, just giving an intellectual answer to an intellectual question.

The subject was Prarabdha, and the gentleman answered loudly, and I could see from behind how Swami’s posture changed, and I heard his voice change from very polite and calm. Suddenly, there was an authority in his voice, and he looked across the table with a gaze—I couldn’t see his gaze, but I imagine it was one of those that goes through your eyes and down to your toes.

**“Do you know how much Karma you have on your shoulders?”**

Prarabdha Karma is the karma we have in this life. If an arrow has been shot, it will continue at full speed until it hits the ground. Okay. **Do you know how much Karma you have on your shoulders?**

And the gentleman’s demeanor changed.  
The expression in his eyes, the expression on his face—and he said nothing. His hands went up, his head bowed, and he said,

You know, the change was **instantaneous and permanent**. That was the remarkable thing. The change was immediate, not temporary—**permanent**.

And Swami would say, “Oh, you know these things take time, be patient, don’t worry, be patient.” And he was not patient at all.

## The Alchemy of Attention: From Distraction to Divine Remembrance

The story of Norman—the self-deprecating Texan with his dollar-bill ID and sudden, life-altering vision of love while reading *Sports Illustrated*—reveals something essential about Bhakti. It isn’t manufactured; it’s *awakened*. It surfaces not in spite of our quirks, but often through them. Norman wasn’t trying to achieve a spiritual breakthrough. He was simply being himself, engaged in a mundane activity, when grace descended and re-wired his perception of reality. From that day forward, he was never lonely again. He didn't become a saint; he remained a businessman with a wry sense of humor, but his inner center of gravity had irrevocably shifted.

This points to a profound truth: the initial stages of spiritual practice are less about *attaining* something new and more about *uncovering* a connection that is already there, buried under layers of habit and distraction. The mind, accustomed to its worldly entanglements, does not easily turn toward God. The initial efforts can feel clumsy, even futile.

**The initial struggle is not a sign of failure; it is the friction of reorientation.**

### The Power of the Chosen Ideal & The Mantra

This is where the two crucial pillars of practice in our tradition come in: the **Chosen Ideal of God** (Ishta) and the **Mantra**.

Your Chosen Ideal is that particular facet of the Divine that naturally captivates your heart—be it as a protective mother, a compassionate friend, a divine child, or a stern but just king. Their stories, their teachings, their very image, should stir a feeling of enthusiasm and love within you. As a young man new to this path, I understood this intellectually. The logic was clear: by deeply contemplating a divine personality whose qualities you admire, those very qualities begin to cast their shadow upon you.

But the second pillar, the Mantra, was initially a mystery to me. In the early 70s, amidst the influx of Eastern traditions, mantra meditation was becoming popular, yet I was skeptical. My skepticism was ironically cemented by a scientific study that found no difference in measured physiological effects between chanting Sanskrit mantras and repeating the word "Coca-Cola." It seemed to reduce this sacred tool to a mere sound.

My perspective changed through a personal, and somewhat comical, misadventure. Hearing an elderly swami chanting what I thought was a mantra with such devotion, I decided to try it myself. The effect was immediate and powerful. In my demanding job working with troubled teens, this practice created a profound sense of detachment. I became like an observer watching a show, unfazed by their attempts to provoke me. While this was initially pleasant, I soon realized it was a problem. I was being paid to *engage*, not to witness dispassionately.

When I confessed this to the elderly swami, he was aghast. I had been unknowingly using a mantra meant for the path of knowledge (Jnana), which cultivates witness consciousness. It was the wrong tool for my devotional temperament. Later, when I received a mantra aligned with Bhakti, the effect was entirely different—it was warm, connective, and heart-opening.

**A mantra is not a neutral sound. It is a seed of consciousness, impregnated with a specific spiritual power (Shakti) that germinates a particular devotional mood (Bhava).**

When you repeat a mantra over time, you begin to inhabit the devotional mood it generates. I could never have imagined how a single, simple word could so dramatically alter the texture of one’s life. I still cannot explain it intellectually, but from experience, I understand it works—especially when it is given by someone in whom the flame of divine love is already burning.

### The Shift in Center: From "How are you?" to "I am fine."

This entire journey of Bhakti precipitates a fundamental shift in our center of gravity. We see this in how we answer the most mundane of questions: "How are you?"

In our conventional culture, this question is addressed to our empirical self—our health, our job, our investments, our family. And we are expected to give a brief, socially acceptable, and almost always positive answer. My aunt would expertly deflect the question to talk about her children and grandchildren. A devotee named Veronica, however, would ask "How are you?" and genuinely want to know *everything*, no matter how difficult. Answering her was like taking a medicine; you had to pay for it.

But when we progress on this path of devotion, a change occurs. Our attention becomes focused on how we are doing in our *inner life*. The physical and material circumstances still exist, but they move from the center to the periphery.

I have a friend, a wonderfully simple and direct woman, who exemplified this. In her late 80s, she went to a clinic and a young doctor asked her the routine question. She proceeded to list her ailments—a heart valve, arthritis, and several other age-related issues. The doctor listened intently, his head sinking lower with each new condition. When she finished, she looked at him, broke into a girlish laugh, and said, **"But I am fine."**

Her body was falling apart, but *she* was fine. Her identity was no longer fused with her physical vessel. This is the freedom Bhakti offers.

In Hindu imagery, Yama, the god of death, carries a noose. If we think we are the body, and the body is dying, most people don't want to go. So Yama needs a noose to pull us out. On the other hand, if we are focused on our inner life and regard the body as peripheral, we can witness the process of the body dying and say, "I am fine." We can actively participate in the process of dying. It is entirely different, and Yama has much less work to do. He doesn't need to pull us out.

### Maintaining the Devotional Mood Amidst Distractions

The final, practical challenge is this: how do we maintain this devotional focus when the world constantly intrudes? How do we go to the altar or sit for meditation with a heart full of love when we are still simmering from a recent annoyance?

The comic strip *Peanuts* offers a perfect illustration. Lucy is holding forth on her modern philosophies, until Pigpen, covered in dust, walks by and disrupts her. You see her face contort in rage, speed lines coming from her mouth as she screams at him. In the next panels, Pigpen is sent flying. She then composes herself, turns back to the reader, and says, **"I love mankind... it's people I can't stand!!"**

So how do we deal with the "people we can't stand" who threaten our hard-won peace?

One powerful method is to *bless them*. If someone is disturbing you during your meditation, bless them. Pray for their welfare. As you pray for their well-being, a remarkable thing happens: *you* start to feel better, and the mental image of them that was agitating you begins to soften. Then you can regain your concentration and continue your practice.

This is not about being a doormat; it is about actively wielding a spiritual tool to disarm a mental distraction. It is the application of Bhakti as a practical, psychological technology for inner peace.

The ultimate example of this unshakable inner poise was Swami Bhuteshananda, a former president of our Order. It was said of him that "his enemy was never born." He had a beautiful, transcendent smile. On one occasion, another swami was aggressively suggesting that the older monks should step aside for the youth. Swami Bhuteshananda remained utterly unshaken, offering no resistance. As the man persisted, Swami Bhuteshananda finally responded, very slowly and softly, **"Our shoes are not big enough for your feet."**

The message was delivered with such gentle finality that it stopped the conflict cold. This is the power that comes from a heart so established in the Divine that it cannot be perturbed by the petty ambitions of others.

For those of us who have not yet reached that level, the path is one of daily, diligent practice: returning to our Chosen Ideal, repeating our Mantra, and using the tool of blessing to transform our irritations into offerings. It is a gradual, often messy, but ultimately joyous realignment of our entire being toward the source of all love.

This journey of turning our innate capacity for devotion toward the Infinite prepares us for the final, most profound stage of the path: learning to see the Divine not just in the quiet of meditation, but in every face, every interaction, and every circumstance of our daily life.
## The Final Integration: When Bhakti Becomes Your Breath

The journey of applying Bhakti in daily life culminates not in a state of perpetual, ecstatic bliss, but in something far more integrated and sustainable—a fundamental reorientation of perception where the sacred and the mundane are no longer separate realms. This final stage is less about *doing* devotion and more about *being* devotional, where the practices discussed earlier—blessing irritations, shifting identity from body to soul—become as natural as breathing.

### The Vision That Changes Everything

We see this transformation vividly in the experience of Swami Vijnanananda, whose profound vision of the infant Krishna (Bal Gopal) did not lead him to withdraw from the world in solitary ecstasy, but propelled him deeper into service. After the divine vision faded, he encountered a devastating famine in Murshidabad. Against the advice of his brother disciples, he stayed. He did not leave until he could secure food for the starving and eventually started an orphanage for boys who had lost their parents. He spent the next forty years of his life worshipping God in those boys and villagers, "as a mother worships her child."

This is the ultimate test and triumph of applied Bhakti. The highest spiritual experience of being near Brahman did not make him aloof; it grounded him in compassionate action. He returned to the ordinary human level, but he returned with a devotional lens permanently affixed. The luminous soul, as the text states, "adopts a devotional attitude and sees God through the people and living beings with whom it interacts." Sri Ramakrishna called this "the full knowledge." This is the state of being fully on the path of Brahman, where one has searched for the Infinite and then returned to see that very Infinite within the finite.

### The Messy, Human Process of Painting the Wall

A question from the audience highlights a common struggle: the tension between seeking God in special, external places (like pilgrimage sites) and finding the Divine right at home. The answer provided is reassuringly practical. It’s a natural evolutionary process. Initially, an external environment might be necessary to kindle that devotion. But once the devotion ignites to a certain point, you will simply want to abide with it, regardless of location.

The metaphor of painting a wall is perfectly extended here. The goal is a painted wall—a life infused with Bhakti. It doesn't matter if you start messy, using your hands to smear the paint, and later finish with a roller or brush. The human life is a bit messy, and this approach to God can be messy, but you just keep applying yourself. "You keep applying Bhakti to the wall of Maya, and eventually, it works." The key is direction and persistence, not a perfectly straight, unblemished line. The divine discontent, the longing itself, is the "midday sun that heralds the dawn of knowledge." It is that very longing that leads you to God.

### Distilling the Paths: Karma Yoga and Bhakti Yoga

A sophisticated question from an attendee named Ravi cuts to the heart of the matter: What is the real difference between Karma Yoga (the yoga of selfless action) and Bhakti Yoga (the yoga of devotion) when, in practice, they seem so intertwined?

The clarification is essential. The traditional view is that Karma Yoga is a preparation for Bhakti Yoga (or Jnana Yoga). The purpose of Karma Yoga, as Shankaracharya explained, is to purify the mind to such an extent that we have a natural tendency to remember our spiritual ideal or abide in the Atman. The demarcation comes at the point where you no longer need Karma Yoga to purify the mind. When surrender to a personal God, or to the absolute, arises spontaneously within you, the *need* to practice Karma Yoga as a discipline falls away—though you may continue to act if your responsibilities require it.

In essence, Karma Yoga scrubs the vessel clean; Bhakti Yoga fills it with divine love.

### The Personal Experiment of a Lifetime

The final insights bring everything back to the individual's sincere, personal effort. There is no "silver bullet," be it a mantra or a specific technique. If you are of a certain age, you know that nothing is a "take it and you're done" proposition. You have to take it and apply it assiduously. If you are not ready to apply it assiduously, you should wait until the longing becomes a little more compelling.

The most crucial practical advice for sustaining this in daily life is to develop regular habits. For most of us, transforming our lives into a series of "experiments" through regular routines is non-negotiable. This includes regularity in spiritual practice, eating, and sleep. When we live a regulated life, it becomes easy to identify what is causing a disturbance in our mental equilibrium. If we live a random life, it is very difficult to pinpoint what we are doing that is throwing our mind off balance.

You don't have to do everything. The spiritual qualities we read about are the characteristics of enlightened souls; they come naturally to them because they have accessed the source of those qualities. For us, if we take one or two things as our practice, as we advance, all the rest will be included because they are all interconnected.

### The Grace of Waiting

The beautiful story of Swami Satprakashananda's impatience for initiation serves as a profound final lesson. After trying to force the issue and failing, he learned from a senior swami that the mantra, the grace, "is given." It comes through grace. This changed his entire attitude from one of demanding to one of receptive waiting. His longing remained, but it was now coupled with humility.

This is the final, integrated understanding of applying Bhakti in daily life. It is a dance between our most ardent, personal effort and a patient, humble receptivity to grace. We paint the wall with all the energy we have, but we must also recognize that the paint itself is a gift. We cultivate longing, we establish regularity, we serve, we bless, we see the divine in the faces around us—and we do it all with the quiet confidence that our efforts are not in vain. We are slowly, messily, and beautifully painting the wall of our own consciousness with the colors of the divine, until one day, we realize the wall was never really there at all.
